question.title: How to make focusable items inside androidx.appcompat.app.ActionBar
question.body: I want to adapt our application for t9 keyboard,but i can't find way,how to make androidx.appcompat.app.ActionBar items focusable,to move errow keys between menue items,or between menue items and other views. Whether exists way to do this? Thanks.

question_comments.body: I'm in the process of deleting all of my comments with Drive links, because I've decided to stop using it for examples. I kind of assumed that you had it all already, since it's been up for weeks. I've moved it to a Gist for you: gist.github.com/mlmayii/e106f7fa1a46df25ac8af8a5e54daadf.
Why you deleted your link with code. Can you please uploade your code as an answer?

Ok,if it's deprecated from Lollipop,what is alternative for Lollipop and above? It's also interesting for me,whether it possible do something with view with three dots in custom actionBar,or even in custom actionBar i should recursively traverse inside views?

The one that's been deprecated since Lollipop? In any case, there seems to be an additional ViewGroup in the default ActionBar setup that needs the setTouchscreenBlocksFocus(false) call. I've updated the example.
it use to add spinner in actionbar.

"I want to get view,which have three dots icon..." â€“ That's what the findOverflowView*() methods in my example code do. That's why I added them after you said that the first time. The three-dot button is called the overflow button. I have no idea what bar.setListNavigationCallbacks is.

I want to get view,which have three dots icon,to do something with it,for example change contentDescription,or chane nextFocus methods,etc. Whether if i will create custom toolbar it possible,or i should recursively traverse  inside getWindow().getDecorView() to find this view and do something with this. Also i noticed another issue: when i use bar.setListNavigationCallbacks,spinner items are not focusable. Whether it possible to fix this?

I don't know what you mean by "override". If you mean that you want to change the icon, you can do that with setOverflowIcon(), as shown in findOverflowView2() in my example code. If you mean you want to change the function of the overflow button, don't do that; just create your own item with a three-dot icon. If you mean that you want the overflow button to be something other than an ImageView, then maybe, but again it would be easier to just create your own custom item, and use the showOverflowMenu()/hideOverflowMenu() methods in Toolbar to handle the menu.
It very interesting about custom toolbar. Whether i can in my custom toolbar overide view,with three dots icon?

OK, I've made it all the way through the code, and the complete solution is actually very simple: toolbar.setTouchscreenBlocksFocus(false);. That's it. You don't need anything else, unless you can't provide your own Toolbar, for some reason. I've updated the example accordingly, but I didn't delete any of the old stuff, in case it's still needed.

I added a couple of methods to that test code. It's a lot easier to do if you can supply your own Toolbar as the support ActionBar, which that example now does. If you can't do that, then you might have to recursively search getWindow().getDecorView() until you find the ActionMenuView, and then follow the rest of the first method.
I want to get view,which have three dot icon.

Yeah, watching key events might work, but those don't always behave as you might expect, and the only relevant info I could find was that the center of a D-pad is guaranteed to generate one. As for the overflow, I'm not sure what you mean. In my tests last night, it became became focusable just like the rest of the items, so it shouldn't need anything else for that part. I don't know what you mean by custom View, though. Do you really need a completely different kind of View, or do you just want to change the three-dot icon? I think there's a theme attribute to change the icon.

Ok,so to catch item,on which i focus,we should set focus listener for each item,and to catch key events,we can or set onkeylistener for each item,or handle it on onkedown handler. Whether it possible to replace view,which have three dots and which open menue,by custom view and make it focusable.

@Mike M Whether you look at sources of action bar? Whether it possible to catch,what item of action bar was focused? Some items i dont want to do focusable,for example image buttons (because as i understand during debugging,my keyboard focus move on image button).

Are you investigating this yourself? Just FYI, those items are already focusable, so it's a matter of figuring out why the focus search never selects those menu items. I think it has something to do with the hidden View method isRootNamespace(), but that's all the further I got before I had to get back to work.
Whether someone know reply to this question?
